title: Sentence Structures
description: Learn to build complete and complex sentences using comparisons, conditionals, passive voice, and clauses.

children.title: Comparison of Equality
children.contentHTML:
Used to show that two people or things are the same in a particular way.

Formula:

S + V + as + adjective/adverb + as + noun/pronoun

Example: She is as tall as her brother.

children.title: Comparative
children.contentHTML:
Used to compare differences between two people or things.

For short adjectives/adverbs (1-2 syllables):

Formula:

S + V + adj/adv + -er + than + noun/pronoun

Example: He runs faster than me.

For long adjectives/adverbs (2+ syllables):

Formula:

S + V + more + adj/adv + than + noun/pronoun

Example: This book is more interesting than the last one.

children.title: Superlative
children.contentHTML:
Used to describe something which is at the upper or lower limit of a quality (the tallest, the smallest, etc.). It's used in comparisons of three or more things.

For short adjectives/adverbs:

Formula:

S + V + the + adj/adv + -est

Example: Mount Everest is the highest mountain in the world.

For long adjectives/adverbs:

Formula:

S + V + the + most + adj/adv

Example: She is the most intelligent student in the class.

children.title: Type 0 Conditional
children.contentHTML:
Used for general truths, scientific facts, or things that always happen under certain conditions.

Formula:

If + Present Simple, ... Present Simple

Example: If you heat ice, it melts.

children.title: Type 1 Conditional
children.contentHTML:
Used to talk about a realistic situation in the present or future.

Formula:

If + Present Simple, ... will + base verb

Example: If it rains tomorrow, we will stay home.

children.title: Type 2 Conditional
children.contentHTML:
Used for hypothetical or unlikely situations in the present or future. It's often used for giving advice.

Formula:

If + Past Simple, ... would + base verb

Example: If I won the lottery, I would buy a big house.

Note: For the verb 'to be', 'were' is traditionally used for all subjects. (e.g., If I were you...)

children.title: Type 3 Conditional
children.contentHTML:
Used to talk about an unreal situation in the past and its hypothetical result in the past.

Formula:

If + Past Perfect (had + p.p), ... would have + p.p

Example: If she had studied harder, she would have passed the exam.

children.title: Mixed Conditional
children.contentHTML:
Combines two different types of conditional sentences, usually Type 2 and Type 3. This is used when the time of the condition and the time of the result are different.

Example (Unreal Past Condition -> Unreal Present Result):

If I had taken that job (past), I would be rich now (present).

grammarTheory.title: Wish Clauses
grammarTheory.contentHTML:
'Wish' is used to express a desire for a situation that is not real. The verb tense changes depending on the time of the wish.

  • Wish for the Present/Future: To wish for a different present reality. (Use Past Simple)
    S + wish + S + V-ed
    Example: I wish I had more free time. (I don't have it now).
  • Wish for the Future (about others): To express dissatisfaction or desire for someone else's behavior to change. (Use would/could)
    S + wish + S + would/could + V
    Example: I wish he would stop making that noise.
  • Wish for the Past: To express regret about a past situation. (Use Past Perfect)
    S + wish + S + had + p.p
    Example: She wishes she had studied law instead. (She didn't study law).

grammarTheory.title: Passive Voice
grammarTheory.contentHTML:
In the active voice, the subject performs the action. In the passive voice, the subject receives the action. The passive voice is used to focus on the action or the object of the action, rather than the doer.

General Formula: to be + past participle (V3/V-ed)

Transformation Steps:

  1. The object of the active sentence becomes the subject of the passive sentence.
  2. The verb is changed into its passive form (to be + p.p) according to the original tense.
  3. The subject of the active sentence becomes the agent (object) of the passive sentence, preceded by 'by'.

Example:

  • Active: Shakespeare wrote 'Hamlet'.
  • Passive: 'Hamlet' was written by Shakespeare.

Passive Questions:

  • Active: Did she repair the bike?
  • Passive: Was the bike repaired by her?

children.title: Subjunctive (Câu giả định)
children.contentHTML:
The subjunctive mood is used to express wishes, proposals, suggestions, or demands. It often uses the base form of the verb (e.g., 'be', 'do', 'go') even in the third person singular.

It is common after verbs like suggest, recommend, ask, insist, demand.

Example: The doctor recommended that he rest for a week. (not 'rests')

children.title: Imperative (Câu mệnh lệnh)
children.contentHTML:
The imperative mood is used to give commands, requests, or instructions. The subject (you) is usually omitted, and the sentence starts with the base form of the verb.

  • Positive: Open the window!
  • Negative: Don't touch that!

grammarTheory.title: Reported Speech
grammarTheory.contentHTML:
Direct Speech quotes the exact words someone said. It is enclosed in quotation marks ("").

Example: She said, "I am hungry."

Reported (or Indirect) Speech retells what someone said without using their exact words. It often uses a reporting verb like 'said' or 'told', followed by 'that'.

Example: She said that she was hungry.

Key Changes in Reported Speech:

  • Backshifting Tenses: The verb tense usually moves one step back into the past (e.g., Present Simple -> Past Simple).
  • Changing Pronouns: Pronouns are changed to reflect the new perspective (e.g., 'I' -> 'she').
  • Changing Time/Place Adverbs: Words like 'today' might change to 'that day', 'here' to 'there', etc.

children.title: Relative Clauses
children.contentHTML:
A relative clause gives more information about a noun. It is introduced by a relative pronoun (who, whom, whose, which, that) or a relative adverb (where, when, why).

Defining Relative Clauses

Provide essential information to identify the noun. No commas are used.

Example: The woman who lives next door is a doctor. (The clause identifies which woman).

Non-Defining Relative Clauses

Provide extra, non-essential information about a noun that is already specific (e.g., a name). They must be separated by commas.

Example: My brother, who lives in London, is visiting next week. (The clause gives extra info about my specific brother).

Reduced Relative Clauses

The relative pronoun and the verb 'to be' can sometimes be omitted for a more concise sentence.

Example: The man (who is) talking to John is my uncle.

children.title: Noun Clauses
children.contentHTML:
A noun clause is a dependent clause that functions as a noun. It can be a subject, an object, or a complement in a sentence.

Noun clauses often begin with words like that, what, who, which, when, where, why, how, if, whether.

  • As a Subject: What she said surprised everyone.
  • As an Object: I don't know where he lives.

grammarQuestions.prompt: This car is much ___ than my old one.
grammarQuestions.explanation: For comparative sentences, use the '-er' form for short adjectives (like 'fast') or 'more' for long adjectives (like 'expensive').

grammarQuestions.prompt: If I ___ you, I would study harder for the test.
grammarQuestions.explanation: In conditional type 2 sentences, use the past subjunctive form 'were' for all subjects in the 'if' clause to express an unreal situation or give advice.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Which sentences contain a non-defining relative clause (requiring commas)?
grammarQuestions.explanation: Non-defining clauses provide extra, non-essential information about a specific noun (like a name or a unique item) and must be set off by commas.

options.text: My brother, who lives in London, is a doctor.
The man who stole the car was arrested.
Paris, which is the capital of France, is beautiful.
